ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 1. The handouts were extremely valuable for students (such as myself) with no prior experience in GIS. Iappreciated the fact that specific worksheets were referenced in the agenda, so that I could put together concepts more easily.9. The instructor responded quickly to student questions through e-mail, and shared individual student questions with the class. Despite the fact that he was not on campus during the week, I never felt like I lacked support when struggling with an issue.12. I found this course to be extremely valuable to future work and it has important applications for FES students with a broad range of interests. Having a GIS course in the school is essential for building necessary career skills.

Awfully heavy work load; I spent more time working for this class than for all my other classes put together and I still feel like a complete beginner with ArcMap. This being said, I learned a lot and Professor Tomlin is an amazing instructor - responsive though sadistic. I think that the class could have been less painful but it's part of its charm. Looking forward to taking raster in the Spring.
LOVED this class. Absolutely great. Lots of work but fun and presented well.

3: The weekly homework assignments were extremely time-consuming. Completing the assignment required knowledge and skill that were not covered in the previous class, leaving students spending hours figuring out the trick. The teaching was not memorable for me to remember much immediately after class even having spent so much time on the homework.
Prof. Tomlin is exceptional. He is clear, concise, helpful, knowledgeable, able and willing to assist students with all their needs. This is one of the best and most useful courses taught at F&ES.
N/A
I audited this course so do not feel that I can comment on these questions.
This is one of the best courses I have ever taken. Dana is an amazing professor; I loved it!!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Assignments built on each other in a useful way. The complexity of the assignments required many hours in the lab each week, and this made it necessary for students to put in the time necessary to learn a new program.
The feeling of power and satisfaction when a seemingly random and terribly intricate series of steps leads to the completion of a very pretty map after 6 hours of misery.
Homeworks were very interesting!
Dana - he is one of the best teachers I have ever had. His ability to break down the concepts in order to get the theory across was fantastic.
The homework assignments, while time-consuming, are ultimately where all of your learning takes place. Dana works hard to craft intricate yet solvable puzzles.
One learnt to finish the homework with the help from TA, sometimes the GIS specialist, and classwork.
Dana Tomlin is a real credit to his profession. He is clear and enthusiastic in lecture. He is uncommonly accessible by email which makes doing the assignments so much less stressful.
Prof. Tomlin and all that he has to offer--both written and verbal.
Very helpful; GIS is a must skill; the course is very practical and provides opportunities for learning and practice.

The course is very applied. The homework is hard, but forces you to wrestle with the GIS program and effectively learn the material. The final project was left open to creativity, which I found incredibly useful for my thesis.
learning skills
dana tomlin is the man. very good at demistifying GIS.

Dana is anincredible teacher. I loved how he gives you an introduction to the tools at your disposal each week, but leaves it up to you to implement them. In my opinion, his teaching style leads to a very deep understanding of the material.
There was excellent overlap between lectures and homework assignments, and the homework assignments were perfectly designed to give us a solid, working understanding of vector-based GIS.
being challenged by the problem sets each week
Fantastically clear and well-structured introduction to using GIS software and analytical tools. Very well taught, with well-designed and helpful assignments.
homeworks

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Additional GIS help during the week would have been very useful. Stacey Maples and the course TA were valuable resources, but they were often inundated with students looking for help. An additional TA with office hours in the sage lab would have been helpful in completing assignments while using time more effectively.
Joins are such a tricky tool that I'd like to see 2 classes on them rather than one.
In-class addressing of personal problems sometimes took up a little too much time at the start of class.
None that I can think of. The workload is heavy but Dana gives fair warning during the first class.
Lecture can at times drag on, and could benefit from the ability to follow along. For students without GIS installed on a laptop, this would mean conducting class in a computer lab.
More coverage of the homework during the class, at least basic operations to streamline operations.

My only strong suggestion about the course is that the grading structure (point values) for our assignments could be made more explicit at the time they are assigned (rather than after they are graded). I always felt like I was meeting and exceeding what was asked in the assignment but without fail I fell short of getting full credit.Dan
N/A
none
Can't think of any.
some of the lectures could be more interactive. perhaps required students to bring a laptop
Slightly less emphasis on aesthetics in later assignments may help moderate workload without reducing learning.

more exploration of the tools instead of just applying tools to homeworks - often I forgot I was trying to learn GIS for life because I was so consumed with just finishing the week's assignment and getting a good grade.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: This class could really use a lab component. Why not team up with Stacey Maples to create such a thing? A weekly review of the tools taught in lecture? TA office hours are helpful in this regard.
n/a
The TA sessions were very helpful
n/a
N/a
it was great
N/A
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm currently taking courses in urban policy, economics, and natural sciences. This course was one of two that provided hard skills useful to my career, rather than more theoretical knowledge.

Essential for so many reasons. Before taking this class and despite several courses in geography and cartography (my background is in regional and urban planning), I had no idea of the way maps were actually produced. Following the full path from data mining to analysis and representation has been fascinating. I no longer depend on somebody else's data - I can produce my own for a series of topics that I'm interested in, from landscape sensitivity analysis to tracking ancient forest cores using historical information. This class opened countless possibilities for me. Should be a prerequisite for anyone wishing to work with space - land management, disaster mitigation, ecology, geographic economy, political science... this was reflected in the number of students exterior to FES who were attending the course.
Not required but an interest of mine. Has convinced me that I want to work with GIS in my career.
GiS will be a strong skill to have on my resume.

GIS is essential for anyone interested in forestry and forest management. The data presentation and analysis tools available in GIS will help anyone interested in better understanding and/or optimizing conservation/ecological/financial goals.
I wanted to take a more practical course that teaches real skills. GIS offered me just that.

I need to know GIS for my thesis. In fact, I wish there was more advanced GIS courses to learn special tools (Like ARCHhydro), or spatial statistics, or crisis mapping, or open source GIS (like QGIS). Some of us want more geography courses more advanced than this one!
very useful
GIS is constantly cited by alums as a valuable skill for environmental/forestry professionals
I will be using GIS in my research; had very little previous exposure.
I am now considering on working in some GIS analysis into my basters thesis work, but I feel this will continue to be a very useful skill after my course at F&ES has finished.
it provides a solid scientific background to some of the policies that i plan to push for at the urban level

GIS is not necessarily directly relevant to my interests, but is a sufficiently powerful tool as to be worth learning, especially from as knowledgeable an instructor as Prof Tomlin.Also, GIS provides endless possibilities for data-driven insights.
essential skill for my future studies

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course to gain practical knowledge in mapping and data analysis for use in mapping relationships between human settlements, natural resources, and public health issues.
I wanted to analyze and represent spatial data according for research and professional purposes.
See above.
My adviser recommended and I wanted to learn something different - something I have never tried before.
To learn how to use GIS. Practical skills
I am doing hydrology modeling for my thesis. It uses GIS. I also want a PhD in geography. This type of information system is ubiquitous in my field.
learning skills helps my research
I will use GIS in my research.
See above.
to develop GIS skills and to be able to build a foundation for future georeference analysis
GIS is a very useful skill to have. Plus, GIS = data-gasms.
essential skill for my future studies

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. At the end of this course I had enough understanding (and knowledge of resources to look to for additional help) to work on further research in other classes and build skills for professional work. I intend to take the spring GIS course this year to build on the skills gained in this class.
Exceeded them. Although the software is very, very hard to use and I'm still unable to do 90% of what it can do.
Exceeded - I feel very comfortable with ArcGIS.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes
Met and exceeded.
Yes. Exceeded
exceeded.
Yes
GIS skills.
yes.
Beyond my expectations - one of the best courses I have ever taken with one of the best professors. Amazing!
They exceeded them.
yes
Yes. Reasonable comfort level with the covered aspects of GIS software use and analytical concepts, with sufficient foundation for further independent exploration if desired.
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages: helped problem solve.Disadvantages: usually left work until last minute, which made for some late nights.
N/A
Helpful to see different approaches to the same assignment.
N/A
n/a

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would recommend only taking this class if you have the room in your schedule to devote many hours to assignments in the computer lab. Working with classmates to talk through problems that arise during the weekly assignments was extremely helpful. I found this to be one of my most valuable classes this semester, and look forward to using the skills learned in my future work.

Take it but be ready to spend a lot of time on it. E-mail Tomlin when you get stumped (he will seldom give you the direct answer but he will always explain the mistake and add some dry comedic relief to the situation). Work in teams. Start thinking about your model early in the semester. Listen CAREFULLY in class and take notes, Tomlin will not change his pace no matter how easy or hard the topic is.
Take it! Dana is fantastic and GIS skills are really valuable.

Prepare to lose yourself in the homework assignments. Start early, and invest time into understanding Dana's grading criteria (ie. just add a stupid north arrow, even if you know he knows that you know how to add a north arrow). Ask questions, even when they seem silly.
Be ready for the amount of homework!
Start your weekly assignments early, they will take a while and you will have questions.
Plan to spend 6-8hrs per week working through the weekly tutorial and assignment. Little things--like formatting--take time, but can be fun and rewarding when you produce a finished project.
Take it! Great course. Great professor. Incredibly helpful and a must-have skill.
Make sure you understand this class takes work (more than 10 hours a week for me). and dont audit it, i dont think you would learn anything. you have to wrestle with the material.
You should absolutely take it, but know that you will devote a significant amount of time (more time the more you like it).
While the homework assignments can take up a lot of time, I enjoyed having a different type of assignment to break up the reading and papers of most of my other classes.
start the homework right after the lecture

There is really no better way to learn GIS than from Prof Tomlin. If you're at all interested, it's worth taking this course.If you take it, take the assignments seriously and budget enough time for them, as they are the main way in which you learn; be prepared to encounter all sorts of difficulties on the way, but don't hesitate to seek help in overcoming them. This is very much a learning-by-doing course, so be courageous and plunge right into it.
ask questions and be involved in the work, don't just complete the assignments
